</td></tr>
<tr bgcolor="#CCCCCC">
<td> — </td>
<td> <i>World</i> </td>
<td> 686 </td>
<td> 651 </td>
<td> 704 </td>
<td> 675
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td colspan="6"> <i>Source: <a href="/w/index.php?title=FAO&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="FAO (page does not exist)">UN Food &amp; Agriculture Organization</a></i> <sup id="cite_ref-66" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-66">[66]</a></sup>
</td></tr></table>
<p>There are substantial differences in wheat farming, trading, policy, sector growth, and wheat uses in different regions of the world. In the EU and Canada for instance, there is significant addition of wheat to animal feeds, but less so in the USA.
</p><p>The biggest <a href="/wiki/International_wheat_production_statistics" title="International wheat production statistics">wheat producer</a> in 2010 was <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">EU-27</a>, followed by China, India, USA and Russian Federation.<sup id="cite_ref-wflour1_67-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wflour1-67">[67]</a></sup>
</p><p>The largest exporters of wheat in 2009 were, in order of exported quantities: United States, EU-27, Canada, Russian Federation, Australia, Ukraine and Kazakhstan. Upon the results of 2011, <a href="/wiki/Ukraine" title="Ukraine">Ukraine</a> became the world's sixth wheat exporter as well.<sup id="cite_ref-68" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-68">[68]</a></sup> The largest importers of wheat in 2009 were, in order of imported quantities: Egypt, EU-27, Brazil, Indonesia, Algeria and Japan.  EU-27 was on both export and import list, because EU countries such as Italy and Spain imported wheat, while other EU-27 countries exported their harvest. The <a href="/wiki/Black_Sea" title="Black Sea">Black Sea</a> region&#160;– which includes Kazakhstan, the Russian Federation and Ukraine&#160;– is amongst the most promising area for grain exporters; it possess significant production potential in terms of both wheat yield and area increases. The Black Sea region is also located close to the traditional grain importers in the Middle East, North Africa and Central Asia.<sup id="cite_ref-wflour1_67-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wflour1-67">[67]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the rapidly developing countries of Asia, westernization of diets associated with increasing prosperity is leading to growth in <i>per capita</i> demand for wheat at the expense of the other food staples.
</p><p>In the past, there has been significant governmental intervention in wheat markets, such as price supports in the USA and farm payments in the EU. In the EU these subsidies have encouraged heavy use of fertilizer inputs with resulting high crop yields. In Australia and Argentina direct government subsidies are much lower.<sup id="cite_ref-69" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-69">[69]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="World.27s_most_productive_wheat_farms_and_farmers">World's most productive wheat farms and farmers</span></h3>
<p>The average world farm yield for wheat was 3.1 tonnes per hectare, in 2010.
</p><p>Dutch wheat farms were the most productive in 2010, with a nationwide average of 8.9 tonnes per hectare.<sup id="cite_ref-70" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-70">[70]</a></sup> Belgium was a close second.
</p><p>Various regions of the world hold wheat production yield contests every year. Yields above 12 tonnes per hectare are routinely achieved in many parts of the world. Chris Dennison of Oamaru, New Zealand, set a world record for wheat yield in 2003 at 15.015 tonnes per hectare (223 bushels/acre). In 2010, this record was surpassed by another New Zealand farmer, Michael Solari, with 15.636  tonnes per hectare (232.64 bushels/acre) at Otama, Gore.<sup id="cite_ref-71" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-71">[71]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Agronomy">Agronomy</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Spiklet.jpg" title="File:Spiklet.jpg">File:Spiklet.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Wheat spikelet with the three anthers sticking out</div></div></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Crop_development">Crop development</span></h3>
<p>Wheat normally needs between 110 and 130 days between sowing and harvest, depending upon climate, seed type, and soil conditions (winter wheat lies dormant during a winter freeze). Optimal crop management requires that the farmer have a detailed understanding of each stage of development in the growing plants. In particular, spring <a href="/wiki/Fertilizer" title="Fertilizer">fertilizers</a>, <a href="/wiki/Herbicide" title="Herbicide">herbicides</a>, <a href="/wiki/Fungicide" title="Fungicide">fungicides</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Plant_hormone" title="Plant hormone">growth regulators</a> are typically applied only at specific stages of plant development. For example, it is currently recommended that the second application of nitrogen is best done when the ear (not visible at this stage) is about 1&#160;cm in size (Z31 on <a href="/wiki/Zadoks_scale" title="Zadoks scale">Zadoks scale</a>). Knowledge of stages is also important to identify periods of higher risk from the climate. For example, pollen formation from the mother cell, and the stages between <a href="/w/index.php?title=Anthesis&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Anthesis (page does not exist)">anthesis</a> and maturity are susceptible to high temperatures, and this adverse effect is made worse by water stress.<sup id="cite_ref-72" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-72">[72]</a></sup>  Farmers also benefit from knowing when the 'flag leaf' (last leaf) appears, as this leaf represents about 75% of photosynthesis reactions during the grain filling period, and so should be preserved from disease or insect attacks to ensure a good yield.
</p><p>Several systems exist to identify crop stages, with the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Feekes_scale&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Feekes scale (page does not exist)">Feekes</a> and <a href="/wiki/Zadoks_scale" title="Zadoks scale">Zadoks scales</a> being the most widely used. Each scale is a standard system which describes successive stages reached by the crop during the agricultural season.
</p><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Triple_image&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Triple image (page does not exist)">Template:Triple image</a>
</p>
<div style="clear:both;"></div>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Diseases">Diseases</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
There are many wheat diseases, mainly caused by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Fungi&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Fungi (page does not exist)">fungi</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bacteria&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bacteria (page does not exist)">bacteria</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Viruses" title="Viruses" class="mw-redirect">viruses</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-73" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-73">[73]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Transgenic_plant" title="Transgenic plant" class="mw-redirect">Plant breeding</a> to develop new disease-resistant varieties, and sound crop management practices are important for preventing disease. Fungicides, used to prevent the significant crop losses from fungal disease, can be a significant variable cost in wheat production. Estimates of the amount of wheat production lost owing to plant diseases vary between 10–25% in Missouri.<sup id="cite_ref-74" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-74">[74]</a></sup> A wide range of organisms infect wheat, of which the most important are viruses and fungi.<sup id="cite_ref-75" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-75">[75]</a></sup>
</p><p>The main wheat-disease categories are:
</p>
<ul>
<li>Seed-borne diseases: these include seed-borne scab, seed-borne <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Stagonospora&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Stagonospora (page does not exist)">Stagonospora</a></i> (previously known as <i>Septoria</i>), <a href="/w/index.php?title=Common_bunt&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Common bunt (page does not exist)">common bunt</a> (stinking smut), and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Loose_smut&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Loose smut (page does not exist)">loose smut</a>. These are managed with <a href="/wiki/Fungicide" title="Fungicide">fungicides</a>.
</li>
<li>Leaf- and head- <a href="/wiki/Blight" title="Blight">blight</a> diseases: Powdery mildew, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Wheat_leaf_rust&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Wheat leaf rust (page does not exist)">leaf rust</a>, <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Septoria_tritici&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Septoria tritici (page does not exist)">Septoria tritici</a></i> leaf blotch, <i>Stagonospora</i> (<i>Septoria</i>) nodorum leaf and glume blotch, and <i><a href="/wiki/Fusarium" title="Fusarium">Fusarium</a></i> head scab.<sup id="cite_ref-76" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-76">[76]</a></sup>
</li>
<li>Crown and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Root_rot&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Root rot (page does not exist)">root rot</a> diseases: Two of the more important of these are '<a href="/w/index.php?title=Take-all&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Take-all (page does not exist)">take-all</a>' and <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Cephalosporium_gramineum&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Cephalosporium gramineum (page does not exist)">Cephalosporium</a></i> stripe. Both of these diseases are soil borne.
</li>
<li>Stem rust diseases: Caused by <a href="/wiki/Basidiomycete" title="Basidiomycete" class="mw-redirect">basidiomycete</a> fungi e.g. <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ug99&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ug99 (page does not exist)">Ug99</a>
</li>
<li>Viral diseases: <a href="/w/index.php?title=Wheat_spindle_streak_mosaic_virus&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Wheat spindle streak mosaic virus (page does not exist)">Wheat spindle streak mosaic</a> (yellow mosaic) and <a href="/wiki/Barley_yellow_dwarf" title="Barley yellow dwarf">barley yellow dwarf</a> are the two most common viral diseases. Control can be achieved by using resistant varieties.
</li>
</ul>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Pests">Pests</span></h3>
<p>Wheat is used as a food plant by the <a href="/wiki/Larva" title="Larva">larvae</a> of some <a href="/wiki/Lepidoptera" title="Lepidoptera">Lepidoptera</a> (<a href="/wiki/Butterfly" title="Butterfly">butterfly</a> and <a href="/wiki/Moth" title="Moth">moth</a>) species including <a href="/wiki/Flame_(moth)" title="Flame (moth)">The Flame</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Rustic_Shoulder-knot&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Rustic Shoulder-knot (page does not exist)">Rustic Shoulder-knot</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Setaceous_Hebrew_Character&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Setaceous Hebrew Character (page does not exist)">Setaceous Hebrew Character</a> and <a href="/wiki/Turnip_Moth" title="Turnip Moth">Turnip Moth</a>.
Early in the season, many species of birds, including the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Long-tailed_Widowbird&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Long-tailed Widowbird (page does not exist)">Long-tailed Widowbird</a>, and rodents feed upon wheat crops.  These animals can cause significant damage to a crop by digging up and eating newly planted seeds or young plants. They can also damage the crop late in the season by eating the grain from the mature spike. Recent post-harvest losses in cereals amount to  billions of dollars per year in the USA alone, and damage to wheat by various borers, beetles and weevils is no exception.<sup id="cite_ref-77" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-77">[77]</a></sup> Rodents can also cause major losses during storage, and in major grain growing regions, field mice numbers can sometimes build up explosively to plague proportions because of the ready availability of food.<sup id="cite_ref-78" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-78">[78]</a></sup>  To reduce the amount of wheat lost to post-harvest pests, <a href="/wiki/Agricultural_Research_Service" title="Agricultural Research Service">Agricultural Research Service</a> scientists have developed an "insect-o-graph," which can detect insects in wheat that are not visible to the naked eye.  The device uses electrical signals to detect the insects as the wheat is being milled.  The new technology is so precise that it can detect 5-10 infested seeds out of 300,000 good ones.<sup id="cite_ref-79" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-79">[79]</a></sup>  Tracking insect infestations in stored grain is critical for food safety as well as for the marketing value of the crop.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="See_also">See also</span></h2>
<p>{{#invoke:Portal|portal}}
</p>
<ul>
<li><a href="/wiki/Bran" title="Bran">Bran</a>
</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Chaff" title="Chaff">Chaff</a>
</li>
<li><a href="/w/index.php?title=Deficit_irrigation&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Deficit irrigation (page does not exist)">Deficit irrigation</a>
</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Husk" title="Husk">Husk</a>
</li>
<li><a href="/w/index.php?title=Wheatberry&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Wheatberry (page does not exist)">Wheatberry</a>
</li>
<li><a href="/w/index.php?title=Wheat_germ_oil&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Wheat germ oil (page does not exist)">Wheat germ oil</a>
</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/History_of_agriculture_in_the_United_States#Wheat" title="History of agriculture in the United States">Wheat growing history of the USA</a>
</li>
<li><a href="/w/index.php?title=Wheat_middlings&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Wheat middlings (page does not exist)">Wheat middlings</a>
</li>
<li><a href="/w/index.php?title=Whole_wheat_flour&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Whole wheat flour (page does not exist)">Whole wheat flour</a>
</li>
</ul>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="References">References</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Reflist&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Reflist (page does not exist)">Template:Reflist</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Citizendium&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Citizendium (page does not exist)">Template:Citizendium</a>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Further_reading">Further reading</span></h2>
<ul>
<li>Bonjean, A.P., and W.J. Angus (editors).  The World Wheat Book: a history of wheat breeding.  Lavoisier Publ., Paris.  1131 pp.  (2001). <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/2743004029" class="internal mw-magiclink-isbn">ISBN 2-7430-0402-9</a>
</li>
<li> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Literatur&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Literatur (page does not exist)">Template:Literatur</a>
</li>
<li>Garnsey Peter,  Grain for Rome, in Garnsey P., Hopkins K., Whittaker C. R. (editors), Trade in the Ancient Economy, Chatto &amp; Windus, London 1983
</li>
<li>Head L., Atchison J., and Gates A. <i>Ingrained: A Human Bio-geography of Wheat</i>. Ashgate Publ., Burlington. 246 pp. (2012). <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/9781409437871" class="internal mw-magiclink-isbn">ISBN 978-1-4094-3787-1</a>
</li>
<li>Jasny Naum, <i>The daily bread of ancient Greeks and Romans</i>, Ex Officina Templi, Brugis 1950
</li>
<li>Jasny Naum, <i>The Wheats of Classical Antiquity, J</i>. Hopkins Press, Baltimore 1944
</li>
<li>Heiser Charles B., <i>Seed to civilisation. The story of food,</i> Harvard University Press, Harvard Mass. 1990
</li>
<li>Harlan Jack R., <i>Crops and man</i>, American Society of Agronomy, Madison 1975
</li>
<li><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Cite_book&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Cite book (page does not exist)">Template:Cite book</a>
</li>
<li>Saltini Antonio, <i>I semi della civiltà. Grano, riso e mais nella storia delle società umane</i>, Prefazione di Luigi Bernabò Brea, Avenue Media, Bologna 1996
</li>
<li>Sauer Jonathan D., <i>Geography of Crop Plants. A Select Roster</i>, CRC Press, Boca Raton
</li>
</ul>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="External_links">External links</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sister&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sister (page does not exist)">Template:Sister</a>
</p>
<ul>
<li><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.wheatgenome.info/">Information on wheat genome sequencing</a>
</li>
<li><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.indexmundi.com/commodities/?commodity=wheat&amp;months=300">Price history of wheat, according to the IMF</a>
</li>
<li><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/jaco/sets/72157604419390265/">Photos of wheat fields</a>
</li>
<li><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.abc.net.au/catalyst/stories/s1913579.htm">Watch Australian science documentary on developing drought-resistant wheat</a>
</li>
<li><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.wheatfoods.org/">Wheat Foods Council</a> Est. 1972
</li>
<li><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.wheatworld.org/">NAWG</a>—Web site of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=National_Association_of_Wheat_Growers&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="National Association of Wheat Growers (page does not exist)">National Association of Wheat Growers</a>
</li>
<li><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.cimmyt.org/">CIMMYT</a>—Web site of the <a href="/wiki/International_Maize_and_Wheat_Improvement_Center" title="International Maize and Wheat Improvement Center">International Maize and Wheat Improvement Center</a>
</li>
<li><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.hort.purdue.edu/newcrop/crops/wheat.html">Triticum species</a> at <a href="/wiki/Purdue_University" title="Purdue University">Purdue University</a>
</li>
<li><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.genetics.org/cgi/content/full/168/2/1087">A Workshop Report on Wheat Genome Sequencing</a>
</li>
<li><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.genome.org/cgi/content/full/10/10/1509">Molecular Genetic Maps in Wild Emmer Wheat</a>
</li>
<li><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.skyways.org/orgs/fordco/malin/">Winter Wheat in the Golden Belt of Kansas</a> by James C. Malin, University of Kansas, 1944
</li>
<li><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://digital.library.unt.edu/permalink/meta-dc-1510:1"><i>Varieties of club wheat</i></a> hosted by the <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://digital.library.unt.edu/browse/department/govdocs/">UNT Government Documents Department</a>
</li>
<li><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.geochembio.com/biology/organisms/wheat/"><b>Triticum aestivum</b>: facts, developmental stages, and inflorescence at GeoChemBio</a>
</li>
<li><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/sites/entrez?Db=pubmed&amp;Cmd=DetailsSearch&amp;Term=%22Triticum%22%5BMajr%5D+AND+%22loattrfree+full+text%22%5Bsb%5D">Major topic "Triticum": free full-text articles in National Library of Medicine</a>
</li>
<li> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://books.google.com/books?id=GtkDAAAAMBAJ&amp;pg=PA89&amp;dq=popular+mechanics+July+1932+airplane&amp;hl=en&amp;ei=IoAZTePWB-DRnAe63OjPDg&amp;sa=X&amp;oi=book_result&amp;ct=result&amp;resnum=7&amp;ved=0CDgQ6AEwBjg8#v=onepage&amp;q&amp;f=true">"Gold Harvest Feeds The World"</a> <i>Popular Mechanics</i>, July 1949, post World War Two modernization of wheat harvesting
</li>
</ul>
